title: Ticket #7347: Discuss ClassAd memory management
description:
We should talk when Jaime gets back. I've hated the way we do memory management in ClassAds for quite some time, but I'm increasingly convinced by recent experiences, particularly in writing the classad_eval tool using the Python bindings, that the way ClassAds manage memory (in particular, ownership) is fundamentally incompatible with the way Python does.

This may not be 100% true; it may just be that we need to be really careful and explicit about generating new Python objects, managing their reference counts, and handing ownership over to them. In addition to being hard, I think we'd need to add a bunch of things to the ClassAd library in order to be able to make deep copies and/or reassign ownership.

On the other hand, I think it would benefit us, moving forward, to have a predictable and consistent memory model for ClassAds. (For instance, some types of Values are actually references.) It may make sense to leave the existing API alone, because of the large body of code that's been tweaked to work well with it, and create another one -- initially used by the Python bindings -- that might be less efficient, but is easier to code against.
